title: Pimco Sticks With $500 Billion Danish Market as Re...
text:
From the link:

".....Pacific Investment Management Co. is among investors embracing Danish mortgage-backed covered bonds, even as negative interest rates mean investors face built-in losses on some bonds. Data provided by Danske Bank, the country’s biggest lender, show issuers are offering up to six times as many fixed-rate bonds a day as during a more normal cycle.....This month, Jyske Bank made history when it started offering a 10-year callable mortgage bond with a coupon of minus 0.5%. Nordea Bank’s Danish mortgage arm is offering 20-year bonds at 0%, and has laid the groundwork to sell 30-year bonds at negative rates.....“We like the asset class,” said Peder Beck-Friis, a portfolio manager and economist at Pimco in London. “We are overweight, as we have been for a long time. And that certainly hasn’t changed now that some of them have turned negative in terms of yield.”.....The bonds are “a triple A rated high quality asset with fairly good liquidity,” Beck-Friis at Pimco said....."

Note: Both Pimco and its parent Allianz have operations in Denmark. If there are old positions, then Pimco is holding them at profit - risk is those profits may disappear. Implications for US investors in Pimco funds is unclear. May be someone has data on Denmark exposure in various Pimco funds.
